summary: This is the U.S. Government's omnibus opposition memorandum to Ghislaine Maxwell's twelve pre-trial motions in her criminal case (S1 20 Cr. 330). It argues against motions to dismiss based on Epstein's non-prosecution agreement, statute of limitations, pre-indictment delay, and multiplicity; motions to suppress evidence obtained via subpoena; motions to sever counts; motions for bills of particulars and other disclosures; and a motion challenging the grand jury selection. The document provides detailed factual and legal arguments supporting the prosecution's position.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant charged with six counts including conspiracy to entice and transport minors for illegal sex acts and perjury. The Government opposes all her pre-trial motions.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Deceased financier with whom Maxwell allegedly conspired to sexually abuse minors. His 2007 non-prosecution agreement with the Southern District of Florida is a central topic of the motion.

persons.name: Audrey Strauss
persons.context: The United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York, who submitted this opposition memorandum on behalf of the Government.

persons.name: Maria Villafaña
persons.context: Former prosecutor with the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida (USAO-SDFL) who negotiated the 2007 non-prosecution agreement with Jeffrey Epstein.

persons.name: R. Alexander Acosta
persons.context: Former U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of Florida who authorized the 2007 non-prosecution agreement with Jeffrey Epstein.

persons.name: Andrew Oosterbaan
persons.context: Chief of the Department of Justice Child Exploitation and Obscenity Section, consulted by the USAO-SDFL during the Epstein investigation.

persons.name: Kenneth Starr
persons.context: Attorney for Jeffrey Epstein who protested compliance with parts of the non-prosecution agreement after its execution.

persons.name: Virginia Roberts Giuffre
persons.context: Plaintiff in a defamation lawsuit against Maxwell; her allegations are referenced in the perjury counts and the background of the investigation.

persons.name: David Boies
persons.context: Founder of Boies Schiller & Flexner LLP, which represented Giuffre in civil litigation against Maxwell. The Government denies his firm instigated the criminal investigation.

persons.name: Peter Skinner
persons.context: Attorney at Boies Schiller & Flexner LLP who met with AUSA-1 in February 2016 regarding Epstein.

persons.name: Brad Edwards
persons.context: Attorney for Virginia Roberts Giuffre who met with AUSA-1 in February 2016 regarding Epstein.

persons.name: Stan Pottinger
persons.context: Attorney for Virginia Roberts Giuffre who met with AUSA-1 in February 2016 and had a follow-up call in May 2016 regarding Epstein.

persons.name: Ross Gow
persons.context: Spokesman for Ghislaine Maxwell who publicly called Giuffre's claims 'untrue' and 'obvious lies,' leading to the defamation lawsuit.

persons.name: Judge Loretta A. Preska
persons.context: Judge who ordered the unsealing of Maxwell's deposition transcripts in the civil case.

persons.name: Chief Judge Colleen McMahon
persons.context: Chief Judge who modified the protective order in the Giuffre v. Maxwell civil case to allow Boies Schiller to comply with the grand jury subpoena.

persons.name: Magistrate Judge Sarah Netburn
persons.context: Magistrate Judge who denied the Government's application to modify a protective order in a separate civil case (Jane Doe 43 v. Epstein).

persons.name: Judge Robert W. Sweet
persons.context: Former judge overseeing the Giuffre v. Maxwell civil litigation who entered the original protective order. He passed away before ruling on the Government's modification application.

persons.name: Minor Victim-1
persons.context: One of the minor victims referenced in the Indictment. First agreed to be interviewed by the USAO-SDNY in September 2019.

persons.name: Minor Victim-2
persons.context: One of the minor victims referenced in the Indictment. Was interviewed previously by the FBI. Maxwell is charged with perjury regarding giving her a massage.

persons.name: Minor Victim-3
persons.context: One of the minor victims referenced in the Indictment. First agreed to be interviewed by the USAO-SDNY in August 2019. Her experiences are part of the conspiracy charges.

persons.name: Michael Casey
persons.context: Purported agent of Minor Victim-1 who passed away in August 2017. The defense claims his testimony would have been exculpatory.

persons.name: Detective Joseph Recarey
persons.context: Palm Beach Police Department detective involved in the prior Epstein investigation who passed away in May 2018. The defense claims his testimony would have been exculpatory.

persons.name: AUSA-1
persons.context: Former AUSA in the SDNY (Human Trafficking Coordinator) who met with civil attorneys in February 2016 regarding Epstein. Not involved in the 2018 investigation.

connections.description: Alleged co-conspirators in a scheme to sexually abuse minors. Maxwell is charged with conspiring with Epstein to entice and transport minors for illegal sex acts.
Giuffre sued Maxwell for defamation. Maxwell's depositions in that civil case form the basis of the perjury charges.
Villafaña, as a prosecutor for the USAO-SDFL, negotiated the 2007 non-prosecution agreement with Epstein.
Boies's law firm represented Giuffre in the civil suit against Maxwell. The Government obtained Maxwell's deposition transcripts via subpoena to Boies Schiller.
Skinner, along with Edwards and Pottinger, met with AUSA-1 in February 2016 to present information about Epstein, advocating for an investigation.
Maxwell is alleged to have groomed and facilitated the sexual abuse of Minor Victim-1 by Epstein.
Maxwell is alleged to have groomed and facilitated the sexual abuse of Minor Victim-2 by Epstein. She is also charged with perjury for denying giving her a massage.
Maxwell is alleged to have groomed and facilitated the sexual abuse of Minor Victim-3 by Epstein. Her interactions with Minor Victim-3 are part of the conspiracy charges.

events.title: Epstein Non-Prosecution Agreement
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein enters into a non-prosecution agreement (NPA) with the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida, immunizing him from federal prosecution for specified crimes between 2001-2007 and purportedly immunizing potential co-conspirators.

events.title: Meeting with AUSA-1
events.description: Attorneys Peter Skinner, Brad Edwards, and Stan Pottinger meet with AUSA-1 to present information about Jeffrey Epstein and advocate for the USAO-SDNY to open an investigation.

events.title: Maxwell's First Deposition
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell is deposed by Boies Schiller attorneys in the Giuffre v. Maxwell defamation lawsuit. Her testimony forms the basis for Count Five (perjury) of the Indictment.

events.title: Maxwell's Second Deposition
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell is deposed again by Boies Schiller attorneys. Her testimony forms the basis for Count Six (perjury) of the Indictment.

events.title: SDNY Investigation Opens
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York initiates its investigation into Jeffrey Epstein and possible co-conspirators, prompted by Miami Herald reporting.

events.title: Grand Jury Subpoenas Issued
events.description: The USAO-SDNY issues grand jury subpoenas to Boies Schiller & Flexner LLP for documents related to the Giuffre v. Maxwell and Jane Doe 43 v. Epstein civil cases.

events.title: Protective Order Modified
events.description: Chief Judge Colleen McMahon grants the Government's application and modifies the protective order in Giuffre v. Maxwell, allowing Boies Schiller to comply with the grand jury subpoena.

events.title: Maxwell Indicted
events.description: A grand jury sitting in White Plains, Southern District of New York, returns a sealed indictment charging Ghislaine Maxwell with six counts.

events.title: Superseding Indictment
events.description: A grand jury returns a superseding indictment with ministerial corrections, containing the same six charges.

keyFacts: The Government argues Jeffrey Epstein's 2007 non-prosecution agreement does not bind the Southern District of New York, does not immunize Maxwell, and she lacks standing to enforce it as a non-party.

The Government contends the indictment is timely under 18 U.S.C. § 3283, which extends the statute of limitations for crimes involving sexual abuse of a minor to the lifetime of the victim, and that the 2003 amendment applies retroactively to pre-enactment conduct.

The Government defends its use of a grand jury subpoena to obtain Maxwell's civil deposition transcripts from Boies Schiller, arguing it sought proper judicial modification of the protective order and that suppression is unwarranted under the Fourth, Fifth, and Due Process clauses.

The Government opposes severance of the perjury counts from the substantive sex trafficking counts, arguing they are logically connected, involve overlapping evidence, and trying them together avoids requiring victims to testify twice.

The Government asserts the grand jury sitting in White Plains that indicted Maxwell was properly constituted, and her fair cross-section challenge fails because the relevant community is the counties from which that jury pool was drawn, not Manhattan.
